xxl.cursors
Interface PeekIterator

All Known Subinterfaces:
Cursor, FIFOQueue, Join, LIFOQueue, Queue, Sorter
public interface PeekIterator
extends Iterator

A PeekIterator over a collection. PeekIterators differ from Iterators in one point:

  • PeekIterators allow the caller to show the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection.

See Also:
Iterator

Method Summary
 boolean hasNext()
          Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
 Object next()
          Returns the next element in the iteration.
 Object peek()
          Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection.
 void remove()
          Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the PeekIterator.
 boolean supportsPeek()
          Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this PeekIterator.
 

Method Detail

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Iterator
Returns:
true if the PeekIterator has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called.
Specified by:
next in interface Iterator
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection. But be aware that an implementation of this method uses a kind of buffer-strategy, therefore it is possible that the returned element will be removed from the underlying collection, e.g. the caller can use an instance of a PeekIterator depending on an Iterator, so the next element returned by a call to peek will be removed, when an Iterator does not support the peek-method and it has to be buffered, if this functionality should be supported. (optional operation)
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this PeekIterator.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the PeekIterator. (optional operation) This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behavior of a PeekIterator is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Iterator
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this PeekIterator.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this PeekIterator. Else returns false.
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this PeekIterator, otherwise false.
